meanings.def: to attach something, or to be attached, at the top so that the lower part is free or loose
examples: hang something + adv./prep. Hang your coat on the hook.
Activists hung a banner from the roof of the building.
hang something up Shall I hang your coat up?
hang something (out) (British English) Have you hung out the washing?
(North American English) Have you hung the wash?
hang adv./prep. There were several expensive suits hanging in the wardrobe.
Clothes hung from hooks on the walls.
His school bag was still hanging on the back of the door.

meanings.def: when something hangs in a particular way, it falls in that way
examples: Her hair hung down to her waist.
He had lost weight and the suit hung loosely on him.

meanings.def: to bend or let something bend downwards
examples: hang adv./prep. The dog's tongue was hanging out.
Children hung (= were leaning) over the gate.
A cigarette hung from her lips.
hang something She hung her head in shame.
Her injured arm hung uselessly at her side.
Large leaves hung down from the branches of the trees.
The monkey was hanging by its tail from the beams overhead.
The sloth spends most of its time hanging upside down from the branches.

meanings.def: to kill somebody by tying a rope around their neck and allowing them to drop; to be killed in this way
examples: He was the last man to be hanged for murder in this country.
She had tried to hang herself.
At that time you could hang for stealing.

meanings.def: to spend time relaxing or enjoying yourself
examples: ‘What are you all doing?’ ‘Just hanging.’
hang with somebody Do you wanna come hang with us?

meanings.def: to attach something, especially a picture, to a hook (= a curved piece of metal) on a wall; to be attached in this way
examples: We hung her portrait above the fireplace.
Several of his paintings hang in the Tate Gallery.

meanings.def: to decorate a place by placing paintings, etc. on a wall
examples: be hung with something The rooms were hung with tapestries.

meanings.def: to stick wallpaper to a wall
to attach a door or gate to a post so that it moves freely
to stay in the air
examples: Smoke hung in the air above the city.
Heavy grey clouds were hanging low in the sky.
The smell of burning plastic hung in the air.
(figurative) The question seemed to hang in the space between them.

meanings.def: used to say that you are not going to worry about something
examples: Oh, let's get two and hang the expense!

meanings.def: to be in great danger
to delay or be delayed in taking action
examples: The project had hung fire for several years for lack of funds.

meanings.def: to live in a particular place
examples: These multimillion-dollar homes are more than just a place to hang your hat.

meanings.def: to depend or rely on something
examples: The research is interesting, but you cannot hang your hat on it.

meanings.def: to be very easy to notice in a particular place in a way that is unpleasant
examples: Smoke lay heavy on the far side of the water.
Despair hangs heavy in the stifling air.

meanings.def: to cause somebody/something to feel uncomfortable or anxious
examples: The crime lay heavy on her conscience.

meanings.def: to remain determined to succeed even when a situation is difficult
to take a left/right turn
to remain calm; to not worry
examples: It's OK—hang loose and stay cool.

meanings.def: to hold somebody/something very tightly or keep something in a very determined way because you are afraid
examples: You get a job, then you get a mortgage and then you hang on like grim death to your job to pay off the mortgage.

meanings.def: to listen with great attention to somebody you admire
examples: The journalists hung on his every word as he spoke of his ordeal.

meanings.def: to put somebody in a difficult situation
examples: She is being hung out to dry for one silly mistake.

meanings.def: to be determined and refuse to change your attitude or ideas
if the future of something/somebody, or the result of something is/hangs in the balance, it is not certain
examples: The long-term future of the space programme hangs in the balance.
Tom’s life hung in the balance for two weeks as he lay in a coma.

meanings.def: to express your feelings freely
if you are going to be punished for doing something wrong, whether it is a big or small thing, you may as well do the big thing
something that gives you an excuse or opportunity to discuss or explain something
examples: The character provides a peg to hang the writer’s political ideas on.

meanings.def: to learn how to do or to use something; to understand something
examples: It's not difficult once you get the hang of it.
I can’t seem to get the hang of this game.
I never got the hang of negative numbers.
